Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: We do love the Church. If we didn't, we would have left years ago. We reject YOUR idea of the Church, but that's something else entirely.

Religious music is one of the best examples of "Sturgeon's Law" I know of (the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon was told, "Ninety percent of sf is crud", to which he replied "Ninety percent of EVERYTHING is crud".) BTW, Montanism was not condemned solely for having women priests. It was largely condemned for its theological beliefs. Your statement is simplistic at best.

We think about the teachings. If they give us good arguments, we accept them. Crap gets rejected. The arguments against ordaining women are crap, for example.

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

Comment: In the mid- to late 1930s France had the largest and most powerful army in the world, yet they failed to act against the fledgling German army when it violated the Versailles treaty and occupied the Rhineland. The French could have easily defeated the Germans, and removed Hitler from power, but they didn't - they sat back and watched as the Germans grew stronger, and before long, it was too late. 

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: "The only real estate loans guaranteed by taxpayers are CMHC insured."

No. So-called private insurers like Genworth are also 90% taxpayer-backed. The amount of taxpayer-backed mortgage lending in this country went from around $150B about 12-15 years ago to ~$800B. Supply-demand is always shifted by debt because people will borrow if they're allowed to. If you let even a fraction of similar taxpayer-facilitated debt for leveraged investing in any other sector, that sector's value would skyrocket too.

Re: tax, let's set aside capital gains exemptions. As I take it, special tax treatments can vary by province. BC (and others) allow things like property tax deferral (with negligible penalties), "home owner grants", and home reno tax credits. (Even when they try to provide tax disincentives, like the foreign buyers tax, they build in spectacular loopholes that render these measures useless.) It is dishonest to pretend these don't impact the attractiveness of real estate as an investment.

Comment: To answer THAT question, Yes, at some, we do. At one location we have 48 cameras installed with remote access. We are working on a new location right now that when open will have 72 cameras installed. 

But what i really meant by "real time" is in reference to real time data. As our data system is what is used to manage some of the facilities, as it happens - "in real time"

When people are put on the waiting list to get in, we know. If someone move in or out, we know. Every resident is issued one of our photo ID's so there is no "manufacturing statistics".  When people show up and walk into the facility, staff checks them in using our data system. When they leave, they check out. If a site has to evacuate in case of an emergency, staff knows who is on property and what rooms they are assigned to. In order to enter the facility past curfew, they have to be on our late list. If they try to check in past curfew and are not on the late list, it will alert staff immediately.

Comment: Wargames are pretty brutal in their assessment of weapons effectiveness. It's pretty typical to assume that if you let an opponent get a shot off, they stand a very high chance of getting hits, and with high damage output per hit. Wargames are not usually intended to be easy on the blue force. Real history is much more complex, and much smaller carriers than we have today absorbed huge amounts of damage in WWII.

In the exercise, a 40 year old missile design was assumed, just based on being launched within range and with decent location intel, to score a large number of hits and do massive amounts of damage, when history shows both the reality of being able to intercept these missiles, and of large vessels to withstand the damage from them.

There's nothing from Millennium Challenge indicating carriers are obsolete. Only that unconventional thinking is, as always, a potential game changer if you're not on your toes. Gen. Van Riper proved he has that skill.

Comment: A relatively simple but effective way of addressing the distracted driver is through the use of insurance costs.  Just as we have implied consent for alcohol we can come up with an equivalent for cell phone usage.  In all cases where there has been an accident or even a traffic violation, cell phone companies can be required to report on the usage of the cell phone during that time.  We do not need to know to content or even the other party involved with the call or text, just the fact that a call was occurring at this time xx.xx local time, or that a text was sent or a text was received etc.
 
This data would then automatically be forwarded on to the drivers insurance company unless the Police Officer on the scene determines that the call/text was made by another passenger.  In the case of Photo Cops the picture could be enlarged to show the passenger cabin with the relevant party certifying they were the ones making the call.  Is this perfect. Loyalty to party has surpassed loyalty to country for partisans on both sides. This practice lies at the root of what is wrong with our system. And too often partisans will point to what someone on the other side has done in order to downplay what their own candidate has done. The real problems are sexual misbehavior and a government that routinely destroys its own records, regardless of who is in charge. But by saying "they did it too," what is really being said is, "It's OK, because they did it too."

This is why we have arrived at this sorry point.

Comment: That lack of philosophical precision in employing such terminology became evident in the exchange between Radbertus and Ratramus {two 9th century French Benedictines}. According to Radbertus, the body and blood of Christ were "produced from the substance of bread and wine" when "the substance of bread and wine is changed into the flesh and blood of Christ, efficaciously and inwardly" and "the invisible priest converts his visible creatures into the substance of his body and blood." Comment: The argument "don't tax us for other island stuff" defies logic for me.  From a theoretical view where do you think the division should be? Because surely there are plenty things that one island's taxes pay for on another island.  Should each island exist as it's own tax ...island (sorry for that) where none of it's taxes go towards anything on another island?  Which brings me to the practical view...it is more of a question, because I cannot seem to find the answer anywhere online, and it may very well be impossible to answer definitively:  Considering taxes generated, population, services offered, departmental budgets, etc, etc....which island sees the most benefits for the least amount of taxes paid.  My thoughts were that it might be one of the lesser populated neighbor islands in which case the "don't tax us for rail" argument seems a bit daft and disingenuous.  But in the absence of data I cannot really say for sure.

Comment: It's either St. John Paul, John Paul the Great or Pope John Paul.  St. Pope is redundant.  It's also St. Pio or Padre Pio but not St. Padre Pio.  The cult of John Paul started with his youth and vigor, giving way as he aged to counter-revolution - a return to moral certainty in a complicated age.  That is a kind of moral childishness. Comment: The writer offers up what might wishfully be the CBC's last hurrah: the final Tragically Hip concert.  Wow: 11 million of us watched or heard the concert.  Interesting, though, jut 4 million watched on CBC television.  Gosh, folks, back just over half a century ago, another "hip" music group, the Beatles, attracted over 70 million one Sunday night in the fall of 1964 on just one "platform" alone.  There is one overwhelming reason the CBC could never achieve that audience today--nor, frankly, could any media organization: audience fragmentation. Yakabuski unintentionally alludes to it: The CBC "gathered millions of Canadians around their TVs, radios, tablets and phones."

CBC no longer "speaks to" Canadians; hasn't since US TV became widely available. Today, it reaches many fewer. We are too fragmented by over-choice.  This is the final blow for the CBC, because its government funding is based on the assumption that somehow--with some tweaking--it can matter to most of us. It can't.

Comment: I've lived in the Indianapolis area for over 50 years and have attended the 500 race 10 times.  The race is sometimes broadcasted locally as the "Annual Memorial Day Race".  The opening ceremonies begin with a invocation usually given by the Archbishop of the Catholic Archdioceses of Indianapolis in memory of our fallen military. There is a military honor guard ceremony in specific honor of Memorial day that concludes with Taps and an Air Force aircraft flyover in the missing man formation.  God Bless America and the National Anthem are performed.  In 1975 I marched with other Vietnam era vets in the 500 festival parade.  Does this speak to the significance between the 500 race and Memorial Day?  I don't know if you ever served in the military, but veterans remember and honor our fallen brothers and sisters.  The connection between the race and Memorial Day is clearly present. Nonetheless, I congratulate Mr. Sato on his victory.

I don't think anyone is avoiding anything.  But to be clear, you suffer from flawed logic -->if you don't win the popular vote you can't win the presidency.  When in fact, the correct answer is you can only win the presidency if you win the electoral college.

Let me explain, CA and NY matter.  All 50 states matter.  All 3,000+ counties matter.  Each vote matters.  But the way they matter is based on the system (the electoral college) that says, "hey candidate, if want to be president you need to make sure you have support across a broad swath of America.  This is because, as the guardian of democracy, I want to make sure that vast majority of America is represented.  Therefore, I give you a cap on how much a particular place will count in the electoral college.  Go above that fine, but you need minimum support everywhere."

Good day sir or madam, whichever the case may be.

Comment: Voters have the right to write in the person of their choice for any race. King County Elections told the Mirror that candidates are eligible for a write-in vote for a different office, even if they already appear elsewhere on the ballot. A recent example is the 2012 legislative race for the 43rd District, in which Kshama Sawant (now a Seattle City Council member) advanced in the primary for a state rep. position 2 as a write-in candidate despite being on the ballot for the district's state rep. position 1. She ended up running for position 2. 
King County Elections will tabulate the number of write-in votes, but will not tabulate a specific individual's write-in votes unless the count is high enough to affect the race.

Comment: The press getting hysterical about the "Lock her up" chant is funny. Why is anyone interpreting hyperbole at political rallies  so literally? Did Trump lock up Hillary? No. Did it ever mean lock her up arbitrarily without a trial? I don't think so, it was hyperbole for "prosecute her".

A common chant at political protests in Quebec for decades has been "X, au poteau!", meaning literally "X, to the post", i.e. the execution post. Did anyone actually mean "kill X"? In the heat of the moment, some maybe, but was it ever taken literally? I doubt it.

It is also bizarre considering that there is a long tradition of burning politicians, etc. in effigy at political protests. How is this any different, particularly since "locking someone up" is  lot less extreme than burning them or calling for their execution.

More concerning is people *actually getting fired* for having the wrong opinion. That is something happening for real.

Comment: Judging by the dividend history, if you bought Sears Canada shares just before Lampert took over, and sold not long after the last special dividend at the end of 2013, then you would have done pretty well - just more than doubling your money in about 8 years.  Of course, the longer you waited to sell after that last dividend, the worse your return would have been.  Anyone who bought after that first great whopping special dividend in 2010 would not have fared nearly so well --with the real suckers being the investors who bought in after 2013.  

And that's where things get ugly.  As you put it, "an orderly wind down is honorable, and bankruptcy is worse."  But in this case it sounds as if the CEOs were deliberately and repeatedly led to believe they were hired to enact turnaround plans that Lampert, and the board, had no real intention of following through on.  In other words, CEOs were hired to unwittingly mislead the public, employees and investors.  Some would call that fraud.

Comment: No question big mistakes were made.  But from meetings I've attended this year and last, I think the board and superintendent are owning their mistakes and working hard to be transparent and proactive to fix the problems.   Unfortunately, the levy mentioned above was NOT just approved.  It is near expiration, and we are beginning the campaign now for a renewal of the levy.  The vote will take place in February.   These mistakes will make it harder to pass, but I do believe we are on the right track, and we are also being monitored now by OSPI to ensure we get back in good financial shape.    The bottom line is our district is still underfunded by the state, and nearly 25% of our operating funds come from the local levy. Comment: We consumed 70 billion barrels of oil in the last two years and have discovered less than 5 billion barrels of new oil in the last 2 years.  The giant Permian basin which is the hottest play in the world has an estimated 20 billion bbls, which is about 7 months at current consumption.  Most of the large fields in the Mid East were discovered in the 1940's and 1950's.  

I suggest that you read "The Prize" by Daniel Yergin.  The first oil was found in 1860, the first boom in 1862 and the first glut in 1865.  The hyperbole in the press - alternating between running out of oil and having way too much oil has been going on for over 150 years, and will likely go on for another 150 years.

As an engineer, there is no technology currently in the pilot stage of development that can fully replace the energy that is currently being produced using fossil fuels.  Politicians, journalists and dreamers ignore these realities.

Comment: It's the same uncomplicated principle, which you refuse to acknowledge or address.  There are ways to behave in bear country that minimize potential adverse interactions with bears.  Traveling swiftly through areas of poor visibility in high-density foraging areas is not among them.

Traveling through areas screened with thick brush or other visual barriers which prevent seeing a bear's approach at a distance is never a good idea.  Similarly it's unwise to place your extremities where you can't see clearly in venomous snake habitat.  Or hike at night in jaguar country, wade in the shallows of crocodile-frequented rivers, or jog through wolf country while obliviously wearing earbuds.

I'm sorry you find such cautionary objections irksome.  AGAIN, if you can propose a way to indulge in your fad-sport without putting others--or wildlife--at risk, I'm all for it, on the previously-mentioned principal that society is not benefited by proliferation of self-centered adult children.

Comment: At a recent income of $170,000 plus rental plus CPP, he is likely to be in his highest pre-death-year tax bracket, so it doesn't make sense to "reduce his RRSP". Indeed, he is still contributing $50/mo. into it.

His RRSP / employment strategy is sound: He drops to part-time work at the same time as he has to convert to RRIF and make compulsory withdrawals, and earlier withdrawals are relatively small during his 3 years of part-time work. By the time he goes on pension, his tax rate will drop.

I don't understand why he is taking CPP, unless he just started, since he doesn't need the money and it will be highly taxed. OAS is not mentioned since now it would be all clawed back anyway, but he might consider claiming it a year from now when he might net something after clawback.

For tax rates, he has already figured out he is better off as an Ontario resident. Since he will spend more time in Quebec, he is advised to check with an accountant about maintaining his Ontario residency.

Comment: I keep hearing how so many billions of dollars will be saved each year, but I'm curious how that can be true. The same number of students will require the same number of teachers and support staff. Maybe a few smaller schools can be closed to save money initially, but even at the school board level, we can't assume that costs will be cut in half either. Sure, we will need one director of education instead of 2, but when the board becomes twice as big, it is safe to assume to many other positions will still require twice as many staff to run everything. City and school board amalgamations in the past didn't end up saving as much as projected, and the same will happen if we move to one system. Instead, we will have fewer choices as parents, and that's problematic if you don't like how a particular board operates. There will be nowhere else to go.

Comment: Hey, guess what?  Anyone can play this game, even the Greens and NDP.  All they have to do is win the most riding elections by getting the most votes in each.  Just because two main parties are currently successfully occupying the centre right and centre left, where a clear majority of voters reside, doesn't make our system wrong.  

What I think is wrong with our system is that MPs do not have enough power to influence votes in the House to best represent their constituents.  I still think that, with the exception of confidence votes,  all party whipped votes should be eliminated.  This would force a majority of  votes to be free votes, essentially approached as they would under a minority government.  Party leadership must convince, not mandate their MPs, to vote a certain way.  The power is returned to MPs and their constituents, away from the PMO.

Comment: Great article! The details of police reform are usually out of the public eye. 

I've just read the relevant sections of the legislation and the SPMA agreement. I didn't see a section indicating how arbitrations would create an accountability system that is "open to the public" as per Ian Warner's email. Arbitrations are usually confidential. The SPMA agreement states that information about OPA investigations would be restricted to the SPD, OPA, etc., and otherwise available only through a public disclosure request. That looks like less transparency and several steps back to the old status quo.

What's the rush? This agreement is being promoted by the office of an interim mayor who was not directly elected by the people. We have a newly elected mayor who will have to be accountable for policing—a social and racial justice, life-or-death issue. Let Jenny Durkan review the agreement and receive informed public comment over a reasonable time period before it is approved.

Comment: "But I challenge you to find any evidence that voter suppression and disenfrachisement produces more beneficial policies and representatives for the populations that have their voices suppressed."

No problem.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew

But I think you're missing the point here.  It is not "suppression" or "disenfranchisement" to simply state a fact.  It's a fact that voters are ignorant, not my opinion.  I'm not saying voters are ignorant, science says voters are ignorant.  Just because someone isn't familiar with the research or is offended by it doesn't mean it's not a fact.  

So yeah, questioning the assertion that ignorant people should vote is not "voter suppression."  It's simply asking a question.  And I don't think you really have an answer.  Maybe, just maybe, it's a good thing that more ignorant people don't vote.  Things might be worse if they voted, have you ever considered that possibility?  Even thought about it?  Why not?  We should question more.

Raymond has had a great camp and did well against Chicago. McKenzie had the long td reception but did not look strong as a punt returner but that could change.  Can they keep both of them?  Butt can contribute after the bye week. He is the best TE on the team but can he overcome his injury history like Gronk did coming out of college? Walker needs to slide back inside on passing downs.  Henderson reminds me of MJD.  He just seems like a tough dude.  All-in-all this looks like the best draft class for the Broncos in the Elway era.

Comment: I will give you an example of what happened in Port Dover, ON. There was an old fish plant, right on the Lynn River, at the bottom of Main St. where the water level at most times is about 3 ' to 4' below the road. When the wind gets up from the SW, because of the shallowness of Long Point Bay and Lake Erie, we get a "wind tide", which washes over the piers, the road, and the lower part of Port Dover. There is also a dam upstream, with a small lake ..... this all on flood plain.

A long comes a developer from out of  town, who wants to build a condo apartment style building. The planning staff said "no", the conservation authority said "no"  .... but our Norfolk County Council over rode  their  objections, and granted the developer a building  permit.

It's too bad council, or other government elected people, don't have to carry insurance like directors of a public company ..... so we can sue them for their stupid mistakes when something out of the norm happens

Comment: "Vaccines have never been proven safe and effective in a Court of Law"

It is not, and never has been, the duty of a court of law to determine if a vaccine is either "safe" or "effective'.

Instead we have a separate legal entity that determines both the safety and efficacy of all medicine, and that separate legal entity *HAS* determined that vaccines are both safe and effective.

If this ever came up in court (and it probably has) it would be a dead-simple case to simply open up the file and confirm that YES, the vaccines are both safe and effective.

Comment: Without oil, Alberta would be--for an undetermined time--a province with a somewhat diminished economy, but hardly a "have-not" province, tip2.

2016: oil was the biggest revenue generator. So, it's GDP would be ... what?  80%?  50%?  30%?  20%?  
None of the above.  NONE.  Oil contributed just 16% of the  province's GDP last year.  That means the province's economy is much, much more diversified than most Canadians realize.  Alberta may not be on the "receiving end" of equalization payments even if oil goes belly up. May not qualify! 

Maybe that's the reason that, last year--a year and a half after a barrel of oil lost 40% of its value--the population grew by 73,200 or 1.8%.  That is the BIGGEST rate of increase of any province last year. 

But, yeah, you're right, I think.  Don't need Saudi oil.

Comment: The author is factually wrong in several instances.  There is no "hard-line" or mandate for land managers to restore all-native ecosystems and eliminate all introduced species.  The term invasive species was codified in 1999 through an Executive Order issued by then-Pres. Clinton, and clearly defined invasives as introduced species which cause or are likely to cause harm to the environment, the economy, or human health. The author fails to mention that invasive species are a very serious threat to our food security.  The vast majority of funds spent fighting IS, by state and federal agencies as well as by private landowners, is on agricultural pests.  (If you are tempted to believe that invasives aren't really that much of a problem, I encourage you to ask a rancher or farmer if they agree.) The author may "like" a species and disagree with the label - but that doesn't mean the species is any less of a threat to others who may suffer due to its presence, including endangered species.

Comment: These addicts are not ill, they don’t have a ‘disease’. They are addicts.

While I am the first to agree that the ‘war’ on drugs’ was an abject failure I cannot see that the proposed alternative is any cheaper or that it will work in any way. What is being proposed is that we ignore the criminal aspects of the drug trade and instead ‘treat’ the poor addicts whose addiction, we are assured is certainly not their own fault and who committed all those other crimes, thefts, burglaries, robberies and the like simply because they were addicted and ‘sick’ and just could not help themselves. All this might be a good idea except that is just not true.

The best evidence available today indicates that the very best treatment centers for opioid addiction are programs that are in patient and have a duration of at least 6 months. The success rate is well less than five percent at these sorts of places and the costs are very high.

Comment: The first time I went to the Gettysburg battlefield, I felt I was at a holy place. Certainly Lincoln himself felt that the men who fought and died there had hallowed that ground. I think most Americans can understand this idea in relation to Gettysburg, Arlington National Cemetery, even the site of the World Trade Center, which is now held sacred.  Why is it so hard to understand how Native Americans feel about their land? 
Today it is unusual to find anyone of European descent who has lived on the same piece of land for more than two or three generations. Some of us who are into genealogy, travel to Europe to find the place where our ancestors came from. That town or village or farm may take on a deep personal meaning and feeling of connection to place. Native Americans such as the Navajo, who still live on their ancestral  lands their people have inhabited for thousands of years, have a whole different connection to place than most of us.

Comment: I'm not employed by ADN so most of this is just going to be guesswork based on similar sites i've worked on. 

When you signed up for your subscription, you created a login and gave them your credit card; that is a different log in than your "civil comments" account.

I can use my "civil comments" account regardless if I'm logged in or not. If someone were to, say, not want to pay ADN for their daily entertainment and information, they get x number of "free" views per day before the paywall window pops up. So if someone were to hit that window, they can switch to a different browser (If you use chrome, you can switch to firefox or internet explorer) Or you can open a "private" or "incognito" window (which are not actually private, they just don't take cookies). Then you get around the paywall but have to relog into your civil comments. 

All of it is too much work to talk to oneself; but some people like to have multiple accounts or cheat people out of jobs by not paying for content.

Comment: . (Colo. Rev. Stat. Ann. §§ 13-15-101 & 13-15-102). 

13-15-101
(1.5) Unless the petitioner has shown good cause why the publication provisions of section 13-15-102 should not apply, the court shall order the petitioner to publish notice as provided in section 13-15-102 and file proof of the publication with the court.

13-15-102
(1) Public notice of a change of name shall be given at least three times within twenty-one days after the court orders publication pursuant to section 13-15-101(1.5).  The person changing his or her name shall cause such public notice to be given in a newspaper published in the county in which the person resides.  If no newspaper is published in that county, such notice shall be published in a newspaper in such county as the court directs.

Comment: That stretch of I-5 is the Bermuda vortex of death.
I was a North Douglas firefighter for 20 Yrs.  and responded to many horrific crashes in that two mi. section.
A few examples include a woman escaped from Salem mental hospital and drove the wrong way on the freeway until she crashed into two motorcyclists whose body parts were thrown all over the divider.
The worst was a drunken wrong way driver who crashed into two cars killing four and critically injuring four others. Of course, the drunk lived.
If memorial crosses were erected on 1-5 from Curtin to the top of the divide there would be one every 100 yds. 
A few years back they did solve the persistent black ice conditions that plagued the vortex of death.
Many times we would be at a wreck, barely able to stand on the ice as traffic barrelled by at 70 mph.
A shout out of appreciation to all those first responders who still suit up and respond.

Comment: And you wonder why retail managers, at many stores, have to approve voids while you wait...

This has been an issue at many retail stores.  It is not a unique happening.

It's hard to imagine, that this store's computers didn't put out regular reports of void activity by checker that would have warned the store manager - or even distant corporate accounting personnel - that there was a problem. 

Some retailers even post this information regularly on break room bulletin boards, allowing checkers to constantly compare themselves to their co-workers.  Some retail chains consider repeated void activity to be a productivity issue as well as a theft issue.  A relatively high number of voids can get employees fired even if no theft has occurred.  

We are talking a lot of theft here.

Comment: Teacher Loan Forgiveness Programs already exist.   Perkins loans, for example, have a program that forgives 100 percent of an eligible borrower’s loan balance over five years. Special education teachers, those at educational service agencies or in teacher shortage areas and faculty at tribal colleges all qualify. 

Federal Stafford loans also have their own built in forgiveness program for teachers. The Teacher Loan Forgiveness program will forgive between $5,000 and $17,500 of eligible Stafford loans if you teach for five consecutive years in a teacher shortage or other Title I area.

Comment: It is ridiculous to hold any manager responsible for every action of their staff, more so as the number of staff increase. Reward and sanction as the situation dictates and then move on. 
The tax document in question was far from becoming enforceable. Do I think it would have been poor policy? Yes. Do I think that it should have been “floated”in the public realm? Yes. When we make thoughts and proposals toxic to a Minister we, as citizens, encourage an environment of opacity or secrecy and often complain long and loud about it later. Comment: A draft of what conceptually became the ACA was assembled in the 1980's in The Heritage Foundation (the leading Conservative Think-Tank). It was proposed again during the Dole Presidential Campaign of 1996. A similar system was implemented by Mitt Romney as Governor of Massachusetts. As a free-trade conservative myself, I wonder if had Mitt Romney (or John Mcain) had been elected in 2008, would he have proposed the ACA? Comment: Sad news for Sequim. Picking Cameron berries was my first legit paid gig back in the early 80s. We used to catch the bus right by the Carlsborg Store; early mornings greeted by Joe the Bus Driver (who used to eat Walla Walla Sweet onions as if they were an apple).  After getting dropped back off from a "long" but honest day in the fields, we'd grab some Jolly Rancher Stix and a root beer from the Carlsborg Store (while being closely scrutinized by Gene the Store Lady to make sure our fingers weren't too sticky) and head straight to the Mill Pond to hang out and swim until it was dinner time. Also, Mrs. Cameron was my 5th Grade teacher! Great times back in "the olden days" of Sequim.

Comment: "Society across the board is sinking."?

I don't think so. If you look at the big picture, society has come a long way since many of us were kids. Racism was rampant, people were often killed for nothing more than their skin color, and segregation and discrimination were the norm.

Other subgroups of the population, fared little better. Not long ago women had next to no rights, weren't allowed to vote, and if they're husbands beat them it was often ignored by the authorities if they ever even found out about it.

We've come a long way as a society since, but today we have a subgroup of the population  involved in the drug trade and they protect their business interests with a gun. The level of violence is very similar to that of the gangs that controlled the alcohol industry during prohibition.

There's also a subgroup who feel they need to walk around armed and dangerous and some of them are just waiting to be disrespected.

Our society as a whole, however, has come a long, long way.

Comment: To be clear there is no "EI coffers" to steal from, and never have been.

EI has *ALWAYS* been a tax and set of social spending programs.  It has basically no connection to employment insurance other than in name.  At one point in time there was supposed to be a segregated fund for that money, but it was so deep in the red that the only purpose for its existence was to obfuscate deficits from the public.

Starting in the 1980's the EI "fund" was eliminated except as a line-item on some financial reports.  There has never been so much as a dime in that "fund", it was really just a sticky note saying "I.O.U. $58B".

Chretien and Martin deceptively kept EI taxes high while reducing social spending that had been lumped under the EI program.

Harper proposed segregating EI funds but that plan was killed off, in a move with unanimous support, during the recession.  Harper also tossed the useless sticky note in the garbage.

Comment: SO:  My bad I thought you were counting numbers laid off versus freight reductions.  Yes there are other things in play.  The closing of the Flint shills refinery was huge.  The loss of the coal shipments to Seward was also a major factor.  Additionally the gravel market has been considerably reduced due to no major construction projects.  Break bulk (the movement of goods shipped from the lower 48) has increased but no where near enough to offset the losses in petroleum, coal and gravel. Passenger service, while profitable, does not have much of a profit margin.  Better then break even but not much and it will always be that way.  Railroads make their money on high bulk, high volume business and Alaska currently does not have much of that.

For a married couple (no kids), the current income exclusion is $21,300 (std deduction of $13,000 + 2x personal exemption of $4,150). The proposed standard deduction of $24,400 and zero personal exemption is better.  Add one child, though, and the current law is a better benefit.  For anyone who itemizes, though, note that itemized expenses will have to meet a $24,400 hurdle vs. the current $13,000 to get added benefit.

Comment: Straying of salmon is often used to condemn hatchery production.  However, it is this very characteristic that has helped to make salmon such a successful species.  It has also help to expand production in creeks where ladders/bypass channels have allowed more fish into streams to use more spawning habitat.

'Carrying capacity' is another phrase often bandied about by hatchery critics.  Surely there is a maximum capacity to ocean productivity, but we don't yet have a clue what it is.  We cannot assume that the perfect number of salmon in the ocean just happens to be he number coming out of natural streams which is limited by spawning habitat.

The Alaska hatchery system has probably been the single best investment this state has ever made.  It has brought huge wealth to the coastal people of this state.

Comment: Now, you're trying to justify your illogical reasoning with idiocy. One can reasonably assume that, yes, over 15 years a real estate investment will have increased in value because (a) the labor costs to build the same property will have increased (b) because land values will have increased (c) because demand/supply increases, driven by population growth and (d) because the materials, everything from lumber to a box of nails will increase. It's called "inflation."
That's not to say that the value of an alternative investment will also not increase, but that is not always the case and certainly not as definitive (Nortel, JDS Uniphase etc.), but one cannot compare a fictitious investment, as you did, to say that it will outpace the value of a house or condo over 15 years.

Back to the woods with you, you silly fellow.

Comment: Westley, the content in Peanuts is social commentary.  It is rife with metaphor, and largely expected to be best fully grasped by adults. In the broadest sense, Charlie Brown and Lucy represent polar opposites, a concept that can be applied to a variety of situations we encounter as we bump along through this life.  Charles Schultz, the strip's creator, brilliantly presents these characters so that the reader can reach thier own conclusions as to his meaning.
So while I tend to agree with your perception that Lucy is constantly taking advantage of Charlie Brown's good nature, others might see her as a pragmatic individual, and still others as merely a practical joker.
Mr. Schultz was doing what all great artists do.  He held a mirror up to us as a society, the better that we might see ourselves.  This is why his strip is still running. It is as relevant now as it was 50 years ago, which is, perhaps, a sad reminder that these struggles will always be a part of the human condition.

Comment: Science does indeed expire, which is why currency of research is important. When you study science, you are taught that articles older than 5 years are typically to be avoided, unless able to still be proven relevant. Regardless, I take issue here with your frequent portrayal of issues such as climate change, as baseless or hyped rhetoric that can be dismissed by selective referral to past events in isolation. In my opinion, this is the same modus operandi as climate alarmists', who identify singular weather events as the result of climate change (something we appear to agree on as being wrong and lacking the correct context). Yearning for science of yesteryear ("In fact, climate scientists used to warn that specific weather events cannot reliably be attributed to a warming climate, even if there was a plausible link." - they still do: see the IPCC reports) seems deconstructive rather than inquiring, and I argue we need the reverse. Science is not infallible, but it's the best we have.

Comment: Each human being has a very unique patchwork of genetic beginnings plus life experiences which eventually mold into quite personal definitions regarding every conceivable topic ... what is good, what is bad, what is ethical, when to be skeptical (and when not), ad finitum. My own concept of "being skeptical" means that in response to some stimulus, my mind is automatically flooded with questions ... What? Who? Why? When? Where? Each "answer" to any of these questions then raises new questions. 

To be honestly skeptical, there is one more extremely important question: "What is MISSING in my own perceptions and interpretations?" This last question delves into the "blind spots" in  any person's responses to external and internal events. This is critical. 

The Biblical admonition to "beware of false prophets" is a statement to be closely examined for the who, why, when issues ... and also the "blind spot". Religious/supernatural acceptance raises questions of what one does not see.

Comment: Most of what you say is true. But to lay the blame on EVs is wrong. Today, most cobalt goes into consumer electronics:  over a billion cellphones, 500 million tablets, laptops, and PCs, and millions of cameras, power tools and other portable devices. But I see no faux outrage over that.

About 120,000 tonnes of cobalt is mined as a by-product of copper and nickel. Less than a quarter from reprehensible "artisanal" mining.  In comparison, we consume 100,000,000 barrels per DAY of oil. Vehicle air pollution causes 53,000 premature deaths each year just in the U.S. alone. The extraction, transportation, refining and ultimate burning of gasoline and diesel has a human and environmental cost that is orders of magnitude greater than from electric vehicle batteries. 

Rather than blame EVs, it would be more productive to add Cobalt to the list of "conflict" minerals and strengthen existing international sanctions.

Comment: what really galls me is selling chum salmon as "keta salmon"

According to the Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission, keta is the second-most abundant salmon species in the north Pacific region. It ranks third in importance to the U.S. salmon fishing industry and is commercially fished from Oregon to Alaska, with the majority of the catch coming from southeast Alaska and Prince William Sound.

Keta, sometimes called chum, dog or silverbrite salmon, average about 8 pounds each and are generally caught by purse seining and drift gill netting. The Alaska Department of Fish and Game projects that 17.9 million fish will be caught during the 2010 season, which runs from the beginning of June to the end of September. The supply for this sustainable fish been consistently strong from year to year, with hatcheries in Washington, Oregon and Alaska augmenting natural

Comment: I like raccoons, too.  Just a couple of weeks ago, I was watching the Rockies game when my cat started making strange catterwalling sounds and went to the sliding glass door that leads to a porch.  I got up to see what was going on, thinking it was another cat, but no, my cat was rubbing noses through the glass with a raccoon!  I walked right up to the door and the 'coon just looked at me.  I'm sure if I'd opened the door, he would have walked right in.  No fear at all.  He hung around about an hour, then climbed a trellis to the top of the fence and scampered off after finding no dog food in the yard.

A couple of years ago, I heard a commotion on the deck.  I flipped on the light, and a really big, fat raccoon waddled off.  I'd stored some bird seed in a cabinet on the deck, and he'd managed to open the cabinet door to get into it.   I have no idea how he managed climb the fence, as fat as he was.  

Had a duck hang around about 4 hours earlier this summer.

Comment: The latest bee census estimates their number to be about 51-trillion.  All worldwide experts on Bees suggest that their biggest threat comes from the Varoaa destructor mite, which has been attacking bees for about 30-years.  In spite of that, bee populations are up, worldwide.  Bees do not pollinate crops like corn, wheat, rice and soybeans. So, bee-keepers do not expose their hives to these fields.  The primary study that might support your suggestion was conducted at Purdue, and studied the possible exposure of bumblebees, not honeybees, to the dust from the planting of neoniconoid coated corn seeds.  This study has been criticized due to its small scale and the fact that the EPA has already determined that this poses only a minor risk to bees.  A study published in the Scientific Journal PLOS looked at neonics' affect on bumblebees in a three state study.  They concluded that it had no negative impact, and in fact appeared to increase foraging.  Science does not support you.

Comment: Laura... I strongly disagree with your statement that a "salmon is a salmon".   A wild salmon eats natural foods (herring, squid, krill, plankton, etc...) ... a ranched salmon eats natural foods.    A farmed atlantic salmon is not a pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus), it is an entirely different species... primarily a trout (Salmo), which is easier to farm.  What does a farmed trout eat?  It eats a diet manufactured by big business, primarily vegetable oil based (its cheap and fattens fish, cows, chickens, pigs very fast... oh, humans too).   When it is getting close to harvest time, the farmed raised trout is given an "enhanced" diet, which entails color added chemicals (synthetic carotids) to produce a variety of pink/red tones (managers can choose the color from a color swatch from the feed manufacturers).  If not dyed in this fashion, farmed salmon meat is gray.   Most importantly, you can easily taste the difference.   It is like eating "pink slim" hamburger vs a good elk burger.

Comment: William Blake: I think you're reflecting commonly held misconceptions about Canada's immigrant population in asserting that it's younger and healthier than the broader Canadian population. A recent Toronto Star report indicated that two-thirds of GTA seniors are immigrants, which contrasts with a 2014 report indicating that immigrants now make up just over half the GTA's population. This suggests that Canada's urban immigrant population is quickly aging, likely because a significant percentage (about one-third, according to Stats Can) of relatively young skilled immigrants leave Canada after arriving here. The Star article also notes that GTA immigrant seniors, who often speak little English, report poorer health and mental health circumstances than do their Canadian-born counterparts. The implications are ominous for the viability of our health care system.

https://www.thestar.com/news/immigration/2017/05/16/significant-health-gaps-found-between-canadian-and-immigrant-seniors.html

Comment: Oregon's athletic director, Rob Mullens, manages an annual budget of $104 million (FY2016). His base salary is $700,000, up $250,000 from when he was hired in 2010, and his annual deferred compensation is $50,000. If he honors his second contract, signed last year, through 2021, he receives another $600,000 for showing up for work. His annual incentives for watching, and then taking credit for, what others accomplish include $50,000 for a bowl bid (translation: winning six of 12 football games), $25,000 for an NCAA basketball tournament bid (either team) and up to $50,000 for academic progress by his unemployed employees.

Lane County's top administrator, Steve Mokrohisky, manages a budget more than five times the size of Mullens' at one-quarter the base salary. Since college, Mokrohisky hasn't stayed in one job more than 3 1/2 years; he'll hit that mark a year from November. If the commissioners don't pay him, someone else in Oregon will, and the next guy will cost more.

Comment: On a point of accuracy:

1984 Conservative majority from 50.4% of eligible votes cast
1993 Liberal majority from 41.3% of eligible votes cast
2015 Liberal majority from 39.5% of eligible votes cast

One might argue the difference between "eligible votes" and "votes cast", however it's only the votes cast that count in the end.  Eligible voters who don't cast a ballot for whatever reason have, de facto,  thrown in their lot with whoever ends up winning.

Nevertheless, I do support holding a referendum on the question of electoral reform should it come to that.  The question should be: Do we (a) stay with FPTP, or (b) proceed with implementing the alternate system as proposed by the government of the day?  That alternate system must be clearly defined before holding the referendum.

Comment: "The children went to high school with us in Ashcroft, rather than in Church Run Schools, back in the late 1960s.'

In June 1961, our grade 9 class in Vernon Jr. High was ready to go to Vernon High come Sept.  Couldn't wait! Except Wally.  Wally was a First Nations kid--very nice, quiet, unassuming kid. He quietly told us that he wasn't going to High School. "Ya gotta go, Wally! Ya gotta go!"  He shook his head.  "Well, whaddya gonna do?"  
"Go back to the reserve," he said.  
"But you HAVE to finish high school,"  we said.

No, he didn't.  And so...he didn't.  The lure of the reserve--the pull of family ties--was too, too strong.  And so, we--his classmates, Vernon itself, heck, who knows, maybe even the country--lost Wally.  

That's a long time ago.  But I'll never forget that day in Grade 9...

Comment: This isn't true. Speed ratings vary by model and tire size and profile. Bridgestone Blizzak WS80 tires vary from speed rating T (118MPH) to speed rating H (130MPH), as do some Nokian Hakkapeliitta studdable winter tires and a few other brands. There are select winter studless tires made available in high speed ratings for pursuit vehicles, up to W rating (160+MPH) from Nokian, Firestone and a few others. Studs are used because they impart additional traction in specific challenging surfaces, such as black ice and snow powder over ice. They also wear less readily, as they typically use a harder compound and reply on the studs to provide supplemental grip on ice.

Comment: I'm guessing re the grammar. 

Traditionally, I believe the rule is that copulative verbs (here "will be") takes the same grammatical case before ("it" is subjective case) and after ("he" would be subjective case; "him" is objective case), however since grammatical case has virtually disappeared in English except for personal pronouns I suspect there is a strong colloquial tendency to disregard this rule. 

What would you instinctively say:
"It's he", "it's she" OR "it's him", "it's her"
I know I would use the latter, the objective case.

I would further guess that the reason for the disappearance of the tradition is that virtually any other verb is followed by the objective case.

Here's one for you. 
Which were you taught in primary school, and which is correct?

I *shall*, you will, he will; we *shall*, you will, you will
or
I will, you will, he will; we will, you will, you will

Comment: The article deals with baby boomers; but, we "war babies" in our mid 70s share similar concerns - and similar opportunities.

My wife's and my first thought on retiring was to help set up our children financially.

Our second thought was how to stay active and continue to contribute to society so we are not a "drag" on it. We both are active in our community (local and national) on policy issues. We both stay active physically through regular bicycling (including leading groups as well as cross country cycling) and some hiking / walking on nice days (i.e. not nearly enough during this soggy spring). While our intense SCUBA days are now over, we remain intent on doing our part to arrest the decline of our planet's wild spaces.

Dementia does not appear to be in our genes; but, oh, the aches and pains in our joints as we grow older. That alone makes us wonder about a comfortable future as we age further.

Comment: Much of the credit goes to our wives and children that we had left behind.My children were constantly harassed and teased in school because I was in Vietnam.Some of the remarks made to them was that I was going to die.Most males thought that my wife was fare game and and was treated with disrespect. Her neighbor would take potshots at our dog with his BB gun.That stopped when I came home on R&R.My wife would have to disconnect the phone at night because of the constant crank calls.My family received this kind of treatment for the entire year that I was in Vietnam.We will always be thankful for one of her neighbors who helped my wife and children during these hard times.When I returned from Vietnam,our plane landed in Oakland where we were met by protesters with dog p##p and rotten eggs. We were told that if we retaliated, we would spend the night in the stockade.All I wanted to was to go home and be with my family.

Comment: This wouldn’t be an issue if it were merely a question of how people choose to label themselves, but it is much more than that: Registration brings with it valuable taxpayer-funded benefits. The Non-Insured Health Benefits Program, worth about $1,200 a year (tax-free) for each person, covers each registered Indian as well as Inuit. Depending on circumstances, registered Indians may also qualify for tax exemptions, financial support for advanced education, and special hunting and fishing rights. At one time, being an Indian carried severe legal disabilities, such as not being able to vote or possess alcohol, but those disabilities have been repealed. Today, the balance of incentives surrounding legal status has switched from negative to positive.
========
Who doesn't want to apply? It proves again that history is all about the name (label).

Comment: Great now we will have all the armchair bush pilots with their opinions . I may be one of them ! Here is part of the problem . The state of Alaska was mapped back in the forties using best practices of the day . A guy with pencil  and paper and and a sextant ( I believe this is mapping term ) . Some of the mountain passes are five hundred feet off in elevations and a quarter of a mile off in either horizontal directions . These are the maps we are using today . This data is all plugged into our modern GPS's . I have read as of a couple of years ago , there were 17 aviation fatalities or accidents with fatalities related to these topographical errors ! How can this be ????? We rely on air charters and small planes to get home as most of these folks are living on islands in the bush . Yes an airport surrounded by houses ?  . We should be getting accurate topography info from satilites to get us better mapping . I cannot believe the federal money is not fixing this ??? Lisa , Danny ????

Comment: Bag limits & harvest report analysis are lop-sided. Subsistence limits are extraordinarily high & reporting by subsistence users is abysmally inaccurate ... & nearly non-existent.
The WAHerd split & now is seen as separate from the Teshepuk Lake herd, while in the past, the entire population was considered to be the WAH.
Population dynamics are not well understood, but the U.S.& State Constitutions are clear. All Alaskans should have equal access to all game & fish resources.  That may call for reduced limits & seasons for all users, but it does not allow elimination of all but local subsistence users ... as happened this year in GMU23.
